# News comment title:
Behind Georgia's War on Trees

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I am anti-war and now I am anti-war-on-trees too. 


There are some progressives in Georgia too (just like Texas) but it is hard to fight against such insanity.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I am anti-war and now I am anti-war-on-trees too. 


There are some progressives in Georgia too (just like Texas) but it is hard to fight against such insanity.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Don't limit this kind of insanity to just Georgia.  My own state of North Carolina and towns where I live are also allowing this exact same thing to happen.  Mature hardwoods are being clear cut so we can see the latest geegaw to buy or the latest "slogan" too many want the general public to believe without question...  This is a disease that infects far more than the Peach state...

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Review: After Tiller Shows Why Late Term Abortion Providers Are Desperately Needed

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The final solution for "pro-choice" infantaphobes: Fourth trimester abortions.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"Some sick people will justify anything in the name of their political agenda."


Ever check out the Army of God website? They lionize freaks who murder abortion providers and bomb clinics. The American Taliban.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I've counseled a couple of families through it over the years.  Rest assured it is devastating and traumatizing for years afterwards.  Those who seem to forget what 1Pokey4 says below or those who somehow manage to live in such a digital / black - white / off - on world probably don't have very much compassion for the actual suffering by every single person (mother / father / and yes, child or children) when a decision like this is made on the advice of medical experts.  It's no less than deciding to turn off life support for a loved one and I've NEVER seen it treated as anything less than that...

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Real Republicans want a fighter, a slugger, a take-no-prisoners warrior who will confront the leftist subversive agenda every step of the way, on every front. McConnell is history, anyway.

# News comment title:
The EPA's New Carbon Regs Won't Kill Coal Plants—the Natural Gas Already Did

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The coal industry has had plenty of time to prepare for this.  It's been coming down the pike for quite a while.  I do not feel sorry for the big coal producers.  They've made their money and then some.  I feel sorry for the workers, the coal miners who often gave their lives.  My grandfather was a coal miner but he died in 1956 of the black lung.  I never got to know him.

Interesting figures you "quote."  Show us from where.  Without the math, it never happened except in your mind...  We'll wait for the links...

# News comment title:
WATCH: These Global-Warming-Denying Creationists Want to Rewrite Science Textbooks

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Well, pi really should just be 3

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
You want your kids stupid, serving fries for a living, by all means pull them out of our educational system.  I, however, want mine to get a factual education that will allow them to become doctors, engineers, or in the case of one, who's dream is to walk on Mars, astronauts.  Public education is secular, not theocratic.  Get over it.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Sorry, need to call your comment what it is.  As much as I understand the sentiment - and am actually totally in agreement.  Calling vulgar names does nothing to make the point - it just lowers any dialogue into a gutter when nothing really is accomplished.  Have to disagree with how you are making your point...

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Yes, but he has a point. I've long said the same thing. The issue is that the pay for the athletic staff should be reduced, but that doesn't mean the student athletes should be paid either.

# News comment title:
Football's Concussion Problem, in 3 Terrifying Pictures

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
all sports must be banned!!

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
To take the risk of concussion out of football, you'd have to drastically change the nature of the game. Rugby does it right -- all the padding in American football makes the players approach the game recklessly, where in rugby, with only a bare minimum of padding (light shoulder pads and optional soft helmets), players have to be responsible in the way they engage with their opponents. Dangerous hits of the type that are commonplace in the NFL would land a rugby player an ejection and possible suspension. But nothing is going to change until the NFL takes players out of the battle gear that makes them feel, and act, invincible.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

This doesn't change until we all decide not to support what's become our version of a blood sport - the modern gladiatorial games where violence is exalted. The NFL is all about money, and as long as we keep feeding it to them, this continues to happen to players at all levels of the game.  (Makes me glad I decided that academics were more important than athletics when I went to college some 35 years ago...)

Lead is cheap, readily available and easy to use.  It will always be in our lives as long as this is so.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Not sure you know where Christmas trees come from, but the vast majority of folks don't go out into the forest and cut one down. Christmas trees are a crop planted with the intention of harvest on tree farms. They are a source of income for the tree farmer who invests their capital with the hopes of a decent return on their investment. In this respect they are no different than the corn, wheat or any other Ag business you can think of. Plantable trees? Great idea and these farmers have those available too, but to say to harvest a tree planted with that specific purpose in mind is "a few less trees being destroyed in the name of God" is just wrong.

# News comment title:
Meet the Americans Who've Lost Their Unemployment Benefits: "I'm Thoroughly Petrified"

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
What did everybody think was going to happen when jobs started going overseas, and/or were taken over by automation?  Those things put people out of work.  I remember one single voice of protest and it was a movie where the owner of a restaurant was replacing the workers with machines (to make things better).  The waitress and the cashier  were being replaced, and the cook was very upset. The cook looks into the camera at the end of the movie, and asks when (not if), he would be next. I thought it was a warning for all of us that the future might be difficult.  I have a plan B which is to dress up in cute outfits and go downtown to the busy areas with my shoe-shine box if things ever get tight. Today, you have to have a plan B.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Automation is a secondary problem. Since Reagan, the govt has redistributed several trillion taxpayer dollars upward, largely to corporations, always insisting that this is "vital to job creation." We now have a fraction of the jobs, at worsening wages, and no safety net. Corporations continue to use this money to expand internationally, building factories outside the US, shipping out our jobs. There's nothing we can do about it.  We're living with the consequences of Reagan's deregulation frenzy, strongly supported by middle class America, and corporations have been pulling off the Great Bank Robbery of the US right under our noses.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


While I agree with what you are saying (that we can't simply keep paying out unemployment forever)... The real problem is that we still have an economy and culture that seems not to care about offering employment - with or without true, livable wages - to those who need to work, wish to work, etc.  Until we move beyond the fantasy that giving the rich everything they want will persuade them to "trickle down" more jobs (It wasn't true when Reagan made political "hay" out of it and it still isn't true now), we'll continue to have far too many people that are simply shut out of employment for convenience, profit, and greed - as insidious and damning as all of them are on the heads of those "job creators."


Not everyone is able to do what you - and I also - did and start a consulting business to keep our heads above water.  Eventually, the government will have to address this inequality on one side or the other: either propping up those who need the assistance or finally standing up to those whose greed and avarice are causing the very conditions that continue.  If I sound "socialist" there?  Then so be it - but those "1 %'ers" are the ones destroying our nation...

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Is Graduate School a Racket?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It's the atomization of work, the destruction of legitimate full-time jobs. We're becoming a nation of freelancers.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
This is not complicated. Universities pay adjuncts less in salary and benefits and full-time faculty get relieved of having to teach freshman classes. It's all about self-interest. # News comment title:
Are Term Limits a Good Idea?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
For federal elections, 24 years in the House and 24 years in the Senate (12 House elections and 4 Senate elections) seems pretty reasonable to me. That's long enough so that congressional representatives can build up experience and do good legislating, but short enough so that you actually get Congress turning over for new people every generation. 

Most representatives are in their thirties and forties at the earliest when they start the job anyways, so if they stay the full time, they'll be "retiring" around the normal retirement age anyways. It also might be good to come up with some type of official part-time advisory role, so that former Congress-folk can help newer ones with legislating without simply being drawn into the lobbying machine (although that does open the possibility of "puppet seats"). 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I never understood term limits: the voters have the power to limit any term---just vote against the incumbent. If people are unwilling to do that, perhaps the incumbent is not so bad.


The underlying problem is that Americans, by and large, refuse to vote. Rather than using term limits (and I'm for NO term limits), we should:


(a) Make election day a mandatory national holiday with only essential services allowed to operate; and 


(b) Follow the Australian model of assessing a $20 fine for not voting unless the non-voter can offer a legitimate reason (e.g., hospitalized in traffic accident suffered en route to polling place or the like). Perhaps even make that a $50 fine.


Of course, the GOP practice of not providing sufficient voting booths and/or limiting voting hours unreasonably should carry criminal penalties of 3-5 years in prison.

I do like 20-year staggered terms for Scotus, so that a couple of appointments (on average) fall within each 4-year presidential term. [edit: slip of the keyboard....]

And we desperately need public financing of elections---elections run with ONLY public money: level the playing field, and keep corporations from buying legislators.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I completely agree with Kevin Drum's closing thought:  Moderation is always better than the extremes so often trotted out from either the right or the left.  But the article fails to mention the out of proportion influence of paid lobbyists and "outside" money that begins to hit as soon as anyone is elected to national office.  Term limits - moderate ones - are a good start; but until the power of money is addressed - and perhaps the Citizens United ruling is over turned?  It won't much matter anyway.  The corruption of so much "promised" for the votes currently asked for will continue; and the United States will continue its decline into more and more of a corporatocracy.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Their view was, "we need to be supporting of the survivor". Their view was, "We can't victimize her again by forcing her to answer questions." Their view was, "Do whatever she wants, and she didn't want to call the police."


This is the WHOLE friggen problem with these "rape advocates".


And the issue is VERY real, because these people are basically trying to overturn the rule of law and put in place a bunch of "just trust the claim maker and bring down the hammer" policies all over the country.


These people have no skepticism, they have no concept of evidence, they have no concept of investigation. Their entire view is, "If a girl makes a rape allegation it's fact, and believe it all, girl's don't lie!"


Mind you, this is the SECOND high profile rape allegation about a college frat in recent year that is turning out to be bogus.

Support your point bucky... or like I said, be quiet and stew in your own misogynistic juices...

# News comment title:
It's Time to Separate the South From the Confederacy

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
“The past is never dead. It’s not even past.”

Spoken by Gavin Stevens near the end of Act I, Scene III, this passage is without a doubt the most-quoted line in all of Faulkner, though it is usually used in support of southern traditionalism or other ideas contrary to its original purpose. 


In the novel, the line refers to how an individual’s past acts continue to resonate in and shape the present. The scene depicts the wrangling between Temple Drake (wife of Gowan Stevens) and attorney Gavin Stevens (Gowan’s uncle) over why Temple wishes to save the life of Nancy, Stevens’client, who has been sentenced to death for killing Temple’s child: 

STEVENS: Yet you invented the coincidence. 

TEMPLE: Mrs Gowan Stevens did. 

STEVENS: Temple Drake did. Mrs Gowan Stevens is not even fighting in this class. This is Temple Drake’s. 

TEMPLE: Temple Drake is dead. 


STEVENS: The past is never dead. It’s not even past.

http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/r_n_rfan.html

# Most liked comment (from the thread):

Lee who determined that the slaves could not be freed because the plantation was not in a "good financial position."  Even though Custis left in his will for them to be freed, they were not until December 29, 1862, just three days before Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation.  I.E.? # News comment title:

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Same phenomenon as the widespread perception that crime is getting worse when in fact it's getting better, thanks to the blood-and-violence focus of nightly news programs. I consider myself fortunate that I have a place up in the mountains not that far from our primary home.  25 acres that are pretty remote allow us to go shoot pretty much anytime we want to - granted we have a 2 hour drive to get there, but there's plenty of mountain behind our place to stop rounds and no one else around to worry about. The ranges around our home have become snake pits of preppers, Trump supporters, tea party types and frankly all of them are pretty frightening people.
